War in Ukraine: Peace talks hit a wall of Russian intransigence
subhead: Despite 'significant progress' cited by European officials, negotiations appear to be going in circles. The close relationship between US negotiators and the Kremlin has fueled distrust among Kyiv's allies, who are meeting Thursday in Brussels to decide the fate of frozen Russian assets.
byline: By Claire Gatinois, Marie Jégo and Philippe Ricard

title: Louvre president and her predecessor trade blame in French Sénat hearings
French court jails doctor for life for poisoning 30 patients, killing 12
The Sarkozys's damning indictment in witness Takieddine's false retraction
subhead: In its final indictment, the French National Financial Prosecutor's Office calls for the former French president and his wife to be tried for, among other things, criminal conspiracy.

title: Fabricated controversy accuses Macron of giving up overseas territories
subhead: Resumed talks between France and Vanuatu over two uninhabited islets off the coast of New Caledonia has stirred outrage among the far right and officials in the overseas territory, even though Paris has no intention of ceding the islets, which grant it an exclusive economic zone in the region.

title: Farmers block roads in Brussels to protest South American free-trade deal
subhead: European farmers fear the deal will undercut their livelihoods, as it would progressively remove duties on almost all goods traded between the two blocs over the next 15 years.

title: Bovine skin disease: Massive vaccination campaign pits some farmers against veterinarians
subhead: The French government has launched a large-scale effort to vaccinate 750,000 cattle in southwestern France as quickly as possible to protect them against the outbreak of Lumpy skin disease. However, farmers' mistrust of veterinarians complicates the immense logistical challenge.

'It is easier to flatter the people than to serve. Therein lies the last obstacle to an RN victory in 2027'
subhead: Populism has never been stronger in France, but there is a crucial difference between flattering the people and serving them, and the Rassemblement National is currently stumbling on that divide, writes Le Monde columnist Françoise Fressoz.

title: In Paris, the number of homeless living in outdoor camps continues to rise
subhead: Outreach teams counted 663 tents in the main encampment areas of the French capital at the end of November, representing between 985 and 1,723 people. The rise is driven by a reduction in available shelter spaces and tighter restrictions on residency permits.

title: A French farmer's distress: 'I found the first dead cow when I went to the pasture'
subhead: Near Benque, a village an hour from Toulouse, farmer Christian Lasserre discovered three carcasses on Saturday. He fears a new outbreak of lumpy skin disease and the culling of the entire herd.
byline: By Raphaëlle Bacqué (Benque (southwestern France), special correspondent)
